I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The background that was provided regarding multilateral environmental agreements, the history of different landmark conventions and their significance to current treaties, and critical aspects of these MEAs are valuable considering my career.
The material was presented in a clear, linear way. Students get a thorough overview of intl environmental law.

Professor Robinson is incredibly knowledgeable and has a very deep, applied understanding of international environmental law. Listening to his lectures was a very rich learning experience. He contextualizes concepts very well, helping students understand the evolution of ideas and laws over time. He is responsive to questions, allowing students to get his unique perspectives on issues of interest to them.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The broad scope of the course on international environmental law tended to make presentations on the different treaties rather sweeping. Much of the discussion were spent skimming the surface and further in-depth discussion of each of the conventions may be very valuable.
There could be more out of class assignments.

Due to the quantity of information covered in each lecture, it sometimes felt that the pace of the lectures was too fast to fully absorb the material. Also, it would have been nice if there had been a designated questions/discussion portion of each class for students to engage in the topic a bit more.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I will be working for my country's delegation for the UNFCCC and MEAs and their background are relevant in preparing me for my future work.

I had studied international environmental law of the UNFCCC, but this course allowed me to see beyond that one legal framework and explore other legal frameworks, as well as better understand the evolution and general landscape of international environmental law.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I really appreciated the course and would recommend that environmental law in general become part of the core courses that all FES students take.
To get a better understanding of the subject matter, especially how laws are made and amended.
I wanted to gain a fuller understanding of the field of international environmental law beyond just the UNFCCC and better understand how international environmental law works,

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Not all my expectations were met by the course. I was generally hopeful that the discussion of the treaties or conventions would be more in-depth. Given the historical context presented, it would have also been relevant to have a discussion on where the MEAs are headed.
Yes
Yes, I now have a much fuller, deeper perspective of international environmental law and how it works.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would recommend that students really have a good sense of the processes involved in how countries reach agreements, bilaterally and multilaterally to have a very keen appreciation of the output conventions or treaties.There is no one path by which countries enter agreements, and countries vary on whether they see the need to be a signatory to a single treaty.
Recommended for students interested in the subject. The professor is friendly and helpful.
This course provides a great survey of international environmental law.
